Player power scaling felt very off to me in FO4.
yeah
The game for me felt like I was very feeble very early on, but then a bit later it just kinda switches and I felt like an ubergod.
I cranked my difficulty up to the highest, then they patched in another higher difficulty that was completely ludicrous.
Not even taking Power Armor into account.
that's because they used the ES type of "infinite leveling" vs the usual concentrated build with limited levels
or rather, infinite skills instead of levels
But yeah, on the difficulty I play FO4 at, I pretty much always have to use Power Armor.
funnily enough, once you level really high FO4 became stupid because the enemys had so much health.
"having enemy HP based on your level in a system with limited damage scaling is a smart idea" - Bethesda
My only gripes with Fallout 4 are the crappy story, and lots of missing weapons from previous two fallout games, and special weapons no longer felt special when you found them.
my biggest issue was the crafting system, while a neat idea in theory it basicially turned the game in garbage collctor 2000

how you could turn pistols into rifles, and vice versa.

The weapon skill design made no damned sense in Skyrim. Using a dagger all game meant you were just as adept at using a club or katana 60 hours on. Compared to Morrowind that had like 6 different melee weapon skill routes.

In New Vegas, for example, there's a quest where cannibals ask for help, but only if you're evil, have high speech, or find clues. You can expose them, help them, find replacement meat, and unique dialogue if you're a cannabal too.
There are multiple ways to fail and several alternate ways to succeed. I feel like this sort of thing was sorely lacking in Fallout 4.
Obviously a video game can't really capture all the possibilities like in D&D, but I appreciate it when they try.
